subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: I agree with the comments of Vladimir Bossicard:  The main goal of JUnit is to write unit tests. From the developer s perspective, every method is a unit
messageBody:
I agree with the comments of Vladimir Bossicard: "The main goal of JUnit is to write unit tests."

From the developer's perspective, every method is a unit that requires a unit test case as part of the development
process. Even the high level functional methods or methods within a public API require a unit test case.

From the QA perspective, the methods within the public API are the functional methods and these methods require a
functional test written by the QA team. This means that there is double coverage on testing the methods in the public
API and developers are not simply checking themselves.

The next level of testing involves system integration and load testing.

Does anyone know of a good product for system level testing, especially load testing a server app.

We have a public API running on a Java application server which we are hitting through JSP pages. We would like to hit
the methods of the public API directly in some sort of multi-threaded heavy load stress simulation.

Does anyone have any suggestions?

Thank you for your consideration.

Mike



Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

> If you test classes, you write unit tests.
> If you test subsystems, you write black-box or white-box tests (or
> integration tests).
>
> The main goal of JUnit is to write unit tests. Although JUnit can be
> used to write integration tests, it is not its main goal. With JUnit,
> you have problems if you want to test the user interaction or really
> complexe systems (-> use of mock objects).
>
> But I agree, the borderline between unit and integration tests can be
> really thin (when does an unit really stop?).
>
> A developer should be able to test what he's writing (in X-programming,
> test code is written before the production code). If you have two
> separate packages for the test and the production code, the programmer
> _cannot_ test everything (his protected methods). If the developer
> feels more confident if he writes tests to validate his work: fine!
>
> If you want to test a subsystem (the public interface), someone
> (normally the QA - the developer should not validate his work) has to
> write another set of tests in another package (and not in the same
> package of course).
>
> In resume: my unit tests are placed in the same package and my
> white-box tests in another one.
>
> My 2c
>
> -Vladimir
